segments.text: In addition to the $800 compensation for eight weeks of work, we were provided a furnished apartment and could eat all of our meals at no charge in the campus dining hall
Plus, any guests that we might have could stay at the, any visitors we might have could stay at the guest house, at the campus guest house, and also eat as our guests at the dining hall.
As Joe's date of expectancy arrived, everything was in order.
And on January 31, she gave birth to our first child, whom we quickly named Stephen Charles.
Selecting the first of those titles from the biblical hero,
And the second from Joe's very generously kind stepfather, Charles Edgar Davis.
Mother and dad quickly drove out to see their first grandchild.
and soon bought their first air-conditioned car so that they could help us move to our new college station address one month after, about a month after Stephen's birth.
When that
day came, Dad and I left Kerrville before daylight in the Ford Victoria and drove to Houston where he had left his pickup and a little trailer that we had made into a quote
moving van by building a cover on what had once been the bed and pickup truck mounted onto a trailer rack.
We rented a small trailer and attached it to the pickup and headed away from Houston
At about dark.
Near the 1st of September.
Heavy rain fell on us all the way to Houston to College Station.
And it took us more than 4 hours to make that drive.
By the time we approached our new.
Home.
On the west side of Bryan at Cindy Lane, across Carson Street from what was then the International Shoe Factory, the rain had stopped.
So he and I, wide awake with adrenaline, decided we would go ahead and unpack and unload all the stuff.

By the time the new mother, grandmother, and child arrived the next afternoon, we had everything comparatively well organized, since the volume of material that Joe and I owned were comparatively modest.

A notable absence in our furniture had been filled because Dad and I drove down to East Main Street in Bryan and found at the Craft Furniture Company a used vinyl-covered dinette table and four plastic-coated chairs for the sum of $29.95.
Paragraph.
As the year began at Nagel Hall.
Once the home of civil engineering.
Located facing north on just South.
Of the G Raleigh white statue.
And a short walk.
Southeast of the academic building.
I was assigned to the office of the full professor who was on leave for the year.
That large and comparatively large and well-appointed office was indeed a blessing for a novice

and it was located immediately adjacent to the office of the dean again paragraph again one of life's coincidences came into play because the new dean of arts and science of the school of arts and sciences for the agricultural mechanical college of texas was dr frank w.r hubert

This is the same individual who had permitted me to become a member of the Bengal Lancers Boys Band as a seventh grader and who was, Dash, by the time I was a high school senior, the principal at Orange High School.

He had been selected by the new A&M president, Earl Rutter, to come to College Station because President Rutter and a number of other deeply concerned Aggies wanted to try to create a stronger relationship between A&M
and the high school leadership across the state of Texas.
Dr. Hubert, a comparatively thin, blonde, and very articulate man, had grown up in Cameron, Texas and attended the University of Texas
His career had been impacted very positively.
By lecture start.
From Orange.
And also Doctor JW Edgar.
The Superintendent of Schools in Orange during.
The war years and later.
The state Superintendent of Education.
who was one of the key recommenders of Dr. Hubert for the A&M post.
As my duties began in the history department, I learned that Dr. Nance was a very stubbornly and unyieldingly
leader of the department.
A stubbornly and unyieldingly determined leader of the department.
He expected everyone to meet every class on time, to be dressed in a professional manner,
and to be available for students in their offices during the normal eight to five working hours.
Since I already had published two articles and a little book, and had two other articles forthcoming,
My arrival in the department had been greeted with quiet approval.
During the first few days of the fall semester, I noticed that a number of the group
Walked over to the Memorial Student Center for coffee at mid morning.
I very much wanted to be included in that group.
But worried that it would might seem intrusive.
If I invited myself to join that.
Group.
Thankfully.
One morning, perhaps the second or maybe the third week, a new colleague opened my door and asked if I would like to join them, and I almost jumped from my chair.

Before many days of coffee, I learned that Dr. Nance did not approve of there being a coffee pot in Nagel Hall and did not want anyone to make coffee in their own office because to him that was quote a waste of time.
On the other hand, since he led
the mid-morning and mid-afternoon walks to the MSC, he obviously did not think there was any waste in walking to the MSC.
Those conversations ranged over every subject in the world, but quickly it became obvious

that there was comparative cohesion in the department and that Dr. Nance was not the chairman guided by the will of the majority of the departmental faculty, but was in fact the department head who made the decisions
that he thought were best for the department.
Early that fall, at a school of arts and sciences faculty meeting, Dean Hubert spoke.
And I thought that I noticed
in his manner at the of the speech.
I thought I noticed in his demeanor from the beginning through the end of the speech was very carefully guarded
And filled with.
Concern.
He walked back to his office alone.
In front of a number of us.
And a few days later.
He stepped into.
My office.
And ask what the group had thought about his remarks.

When I told him that there was overwhelming approval and endorsement, he relaxed and indicated his deep concern about being received on the campus with acceptance and respect since he had not had, since his career had not
yet included higher education faculty experience.
Another speech during the fall struck all of us in a different manner as we went to hear the A&M president, Earl Rutter.
His remarks
which he read very carefully, left all of us shaking our heads with the evaluation that he was not a very good speech maker and did not seem to have a long experience in higher education.
Further conversation indicated that President Rutter, known to one and all of his friends as Earl Rutter, had been born in the Texas Hill Country and grown up in Eden.
After two years at what was then John Tarleton Agricultural College, he transferred to A&M and was a member of the class of 1931.
A group that included many, many outstanding individuals.
Including the then incumbent longtime incumbent congressman.
From the Brazos County area, Olin E Tiger Teague Teague.
Mr Rudder.
Had.
After completing his studies at A&M, met and married his wife, Margaret, from a ranching family near Brady.
And they had settled where they settled, and he served as a high school teacher, coach, in addition to managing the Mrs.
Rudder Ranch.
When World War Two came.
Mr Rudder had been called to active duty and served with true distinction.
As an officer of the Army Rangers.
Most notably.
Leading a Ranger.
Battalion.
up the cliffs at Pointe du Hoc, P-O-I-N-T-E, D-U-H-O-C, the night before D-Day, June 6, 1941.
In the fall of 1940, 1980, when I happened

When I had the honor of meeting General Omar Bradley, commanding officer of all field forces, all American field forces in Western Europe in World War II, he looked up at me and asked if I was from A&M.
positive response, he asked if I knew President Rudder.
And I proudly.
Answered told him that I had worked.
With Mr Rudder on a number of points.
As he continued, his voice broke.
When he said in 40 quote in 48 years of command responsibility.
I never gave a more awful order to any officer than the one I gave Earl the night before D-Day.
Because if he and his men had not succeeded in climbing that cliff almost 200 feet of sheer rocks and knocking out the German artillery hidden behind 12 feet of concrete,
that overlooked both Omaha and Utah beaches.
If they hadn't succeeded, we would have had a massacre, and the war might have turned out differently."
Period, quote.
But we faculty members' first impression of Mr. Rutter was that he was not an important
an impressive speaker.
Gradually, we realized that he didn't expect speaking to be his mark of distinction, nor did he worry about not having a PhD and a long record of scholarly research.
Instead, he concentrated on leadership, which had begun soon after his return to Brady when a local group encouraged him to run for, to seek the position as mayor of that hill country town in 1946.

The manner in which he handled that task in some fashion attracted the attention of Governor Alan Shivers a few years later, who appointed him as the interim land commissioner of Texas to clean up an awful mess in that office, which resulted in the imprisonment
of Mr. Rutter's predecessor, Bascom Giles.
As I look at the highway sign, we have just passed one that says, Welcome to Johnson City, the home of Lyndon B. Johnson.
After Mr. Rutter did such a good job with the, in straightening out the land office, a group of individuals deeply concerned about Texas A&M identified him to, as the proper individual
to take over the presidency of A&M and to lead the institution forward.
Their concern had been caused by more than a decade of rapid turnover in the leadership on the campus.
and the obvious lack of growth and progress there.
Other Texas institutions were beginning to grow rapidly in enrollment and reputation, but A&M seemed to be standing still.
So they brought this hill country
rancher and quiet politician to take over the task.
Paragraph.
When we survivors of PhD programs had read his resume, we were not impressed because he didn't have a graduate record, had never been a
post-secondary faculty member and was without research or publications.
What we obviously overlooked was his leadership ability.
Gradually, we accepted the fact that he identified himself as, quote, the pot-bellied Prexy.
The latter part of which came from.
His student days when the chief executive officer.
Was identified in an area of Aggie nicknames as the proxy.
Even the big light bulb.
Which glowed above.
the dome on the academic building was known as Praxis Moon, a favorite spring target for student sharpshooters.
Mr.
Rudder spent his time
in organizational leadership and tireless work in behalf of the institution in Austin and Washington and other key governmental locations.
Meanwhile, in the history department, we met classes.
normally 50 to 50 or so per section because in that era there were no, none of the large sections of the introductory courses.
Dr. Nance expected us to turn in a copy of all of our tests
And grades of all students were posted publicly, including names, on our doors immediately after we finished grading final exams.
That policy of review
discouraged anyone from having either a high percentage of A's and B's or an unusually large number of failing marks.
We all checked the roll and soon learned that the department head would back us
in any disciplinary problem we might have.
Yet, those difficulties were almost non-existent because Aggie fish were all in class, seldom without paying attention, and in corps uniform day after day.
At the end of the first year, we were all evaluated, and I was pleased to get a comparatively favorable summation.
But since that was the first year in the state's biennial appropriation period, there were no salary increases.
for anyone, including those faculty members who were promoted for the coming year.
My blessing, however, had come near the beginning of the spring semester.
On that day, as I was picking up
my mail in the departmental office down at the end of the hallway on the second floor of Nagel.
Dr. Nance saw me and invited me into his office where he quickly mentioned, quote, John Hill
Has just told me he's not coming back.
He's staying at the University of Houston.
He's going to.
He's accepted a permanent position at the University of Houston.
So you can stay here.
And be a member of the department.
Period quote.
That night, I joyfully informed Jo of that good fortune, and she began to look for a house the next day.
Within a few weeks, she found one at 410 Emerson, at 503 Bolton, B-O-L-T-O-N,
in College Station east of the campus.
It was a pleasant little frame house, about 1,600 feet in size, with three bedrooms, a small double car garage, and enough room in the backyard for a garden.
We moved there about the 1st of May, 1960.
And began making payments.
And began our monthly payments.
Which started.
Began making monthly payments, which started at $85.
We had paid only the minimum
down payment under the GI Bill and soon decided that we would start saving all the money we could for a, quote, dream house, which we might build in some future year.
All around us in that pleasant setting,
We're faculty.
Young faculty members with small children.
About like ourselves.
And it was a. Splendid it was in hindsight.
A. Glorious time.
Nothing needed to be locked.
Uh, there was no.
Worry about breaking or entering.
Our street safety.
Or any other problem.
I got to teach.
Summer school.
So that.
our finances seemed very positive.
Paragraph, meanwhile, I was continuing work on my dissertation, and that work came to a pleasant fruition the second year at A&M.
As the time approached for the unyielding deadline date for all dissertations to be submitted by doctoral students who would graduate in the spring, I still lacked two chapters of my dissertation.
Painfully and.
Carefully, I wrote Doctor Vandiver letter.
Telling him.
My embarrassment.
At not having finished those two chapters.
I admitted my failure.
To him.
and that I had let down my wife and son and parents.
When he received that note, he called me and said tersely, get down here as soon as you can.
before he hung up.
Frightened all the way, I drove to Houston, walked into his office.
He came in and said very simply, get me those two chapters by the deadline in two weeks, or don't bother ever sending them.
Needless to say, I came back and tried to build up confidence and determination.
The first chapter became a reality within about a week.
And then early the next week,
At supper time, I told my bride that I would go back to the office and work on that chapter.
When she asked when I would be home, I told her I did not know.
Depend on how well I did that chapter.
I started typing and somewhere about 2 o'clock in the morning completed it.
Returned home and slept with relief.
and sent the entire document to Dr. Vandiver, later realizing that the last chapter may have been about the best one that I had completed.
Thus, in the spring of 61, that degree was officially completed,
And we proudly walked away from the quietly traditional commencement held on the east side of the main building at Rice.
Back at A&M, Dr. Nance had given me a second year of very positive review, and my salary increased from $550 to $700 a month.
Meantime, I realized
that my colleagues in the department were all very capable men.
They took their teaching very seriously, were deeply concerned about students, and were helpful to each other.
There were no
eccentricities in terms of behavior, dress, or other events.
This team included some notable personalities.
Dr. Nance himself was a tireless researcher in Texas history.
particularly in the period of the Republic of Texas, 1836, and the decade following Texas independence in 1836.
He had been working on a detailed study of the Mier expedition already for years, and that would continue
literally up until his death, when it was completed with a manuscript of more than 2,000 pages submitted for publication.
To his students, his students had given him the nickname Notes Nance.
because of his classroom habit of relying heavily upon his notes and reading a large portion of his lectures from those pages.
Other memorable individuals were Screamin' Al Nelson,
Never forgotten by anyone, this specialist in Latin American history would regularly yell at his classes, particularly as a result of his worry
About quote Democrats and other communist liberals.
Quote who were going to ruin American democracy.
Until I had a class.
Session a class that met across the whole way from his.
I did not understand why he
Why he merited that nickname.
But after.
Hearing in those months.
There was no doubt.
About its appropriateness.
The senior man in Southern history, my specialty.
Was Horace Bass.
Who seemed to his.
Members of his classes to be short.
In humor.
An understanding and thus.

An Easterner.

a graduate of Lehigh University who impressed everyone with the his splendid appearance and the style of his dress.
Among the first to wear button-down collars and ties of
real distinction he was always Ivy League tailor since it was history paragraph since the department was history and government
The senior man in Texas government was Gene Benton, who required all students to take their exams in blue books, then a standard practice at upscale institutions.
So
His pseudonym, so he earned the student pseudonym of Blue Book Benton.
Others who quickly struck this new colleague by their care, ability, and thoughtfulness were Claude Hall,
a University of Virginia product who specialized in American diplomatic history.
Herbert Lang, a UT graduate in US diplomatic.
John Duncan, quietly, courteously,
and patiently concerned to the students.
Another political science, another government colleague whose nickname seemed special was Jock Woods.
who reportedly was inclined not to fail anyone, any athlete in his government classes.
